As the engine clanked away, the ruddy-faced young man paused on his
way up the next hill, and looked hack at the station. He saw the usual group
of jean-clad mountain people and ragged darkies all staring at the half-dozen
picturesque revenue officers as they filed along. 'Gee!" he said," if I had a
pair of hoots to stick my breeches in, I would do, myself. Wide black hat—
gun—blue coat." Returned and briskly went at the steep hill.
He had topped the rise, when he was passed by a lanky, chalk-faced
mountaineer, riding a scraggy mule, who had just left the station. The man
looked the picture of indolence and apathy. He lolled back on the saddle, his
ungainly legs swinging in time to the mule's amble, his bridle-hand resting on
the big saddle horn. He rounded a curve a hundred yards ahead. The next
moment the walker heard a sharp crack, and the irregular beat of galloping
hoofs. He sprang upon a stump. Through a gap in the trees he caught a
glimpse of the mule tearing by in a clumsy run, urged on by the vigorous
blows and kicks of its rider.
Wondering a little, the young man continued on his ascending path. Soon
he left behind the last outpost of the little settlement, and the world became a
vast slope of green, upward-rolling mountain spurs. The pines soughed in the
balmy wind, and breathed down to him a pungent fragrance. He cast a last
look behind him at the tiny village lying below. Then he turned, and plunged
into the heart of the ever ascending forest.
II

Green corn whiskey,fresh distilled, is no gentle drink; yet the gray-bearded
old moonshiner at one draught took nearly the whole glassful.
"Hit air a main good bead," he chuckled, stirring up with a grimy talon a
multitude of tiny bubbles in the finger's-breadth of liquor that remained. These
betokened that there had been an unusually potent "mash," or mixture of corn
and water left in a barrel to ferment before distillation.
The old man picked up a bucket and went to the "worm" to get a fresh
supply of whiskey. This clumsy, big retort, with its coil of copper pipe, nearly
filled the little mud-chinked log cabin. Beside it, a stream of water trickled
along a rude shute into a trough. The distiller picked up an earthenware jug
that was lying by; and, having pulled out its corn-cob stopper, he skillfully proceeded, without the aid of a funnel, to decant into it the whiskey from his pail.
The crouching old man, with his heavy brows and sharp eyes, was a naturally dignified and commanding figure. The effect, however, was hampered by
his torn hickory shirt, crossed by a single suspender, and somewhat imperfectly
connected with his butternut jeans; while his spreading brogans were slit open
on each side, for the better accomodation of his "footso's." This laxity of dress
indicated a corresponding freedom of thought and action. It hinted at the
difficulties in store for any Professor of Governmental Theory, let us say, who
should undertake to show him how it was less lawful to distill his corn than to
grind it.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE FIFTH PUBLIC DEBATE.
N striking contrast to the part the undergraduates played at the
celebration,
on February 21-22, was their role in the annual contest in public speak-

3

ing and debate held on Thursday, February 27. Phrases such as
tween 500 and 1,000 late ticket holders were turned away from the doors shortly
after eight o'clock," and "the debate this year, as usual, helped bring togethe
r
the people of the city and the college men" have become so commonplace in re.
porting our debates that it is best to immediately proceed to a discussion
of the
debate and contest themselves.
The Freshman speakers were all good, but only the prize winner, Licking,
was very good. He was the only speaker who had force, and being blessed
with a finely modulated voice, he was able to hold the attention of his audience.
Humrichhouse had the tendency to let his eyes wander into celestia
l regions
while he was talking in tragic depths of Schley's attack on Santiago. Schapiro had disadvantages to overcome, which, when taken into conside
ration,
cause us to call his effort a strong one. But with Schapiro as with Humric
hhouse the performance idea was too powerful; any one could tell that
the men
were reciting, and not giving their own speeches. All three speakers
made
much better use of gesture than is usual among speakers from the first
year
class.
In the debate, the seniors were fairly out-classed. Excuses are the
easiest
things in the world to find, but one reason for the defeat of
the seniors is so
powerfully apparent that it would be foolish to delve into the
fires and cons of
the matter. The junior team was manifestly superior to that
of the seniors. It
is true that the juniors had the negative of the question [Resolv
ed that: "Trusts
threaten the future welfare of the United States,1 and that
they had the advantage of having the last speech, but their speakers were so
superior in effective delivery to the seniors that even with an equality of argume
nt the debate
would probably have gone to them, Even as it was they
slightly surpassed
their opponents in weight of argument.
Fred. L. (;uggenheirner, who was the first speaker for
the affirmative, tried
to make a dramatic recital out of an essay. Especially
was his dramatic affectation noticed in the wild use he made of his hands.
Otherwise he was excellent. His voice could be heard all over the hall,
his enunciation was distinct, and he brought out the connection between his argume
nts as well as his
speech allowed.
Harry Plaggemeyer led for the negative and, with
his colleague Blum, won
the honors of the evening. Intense, and thoroughly
interested in his subject,
he doubtless made a great many .people think he was
making points, whereas
his speech had hardly anything to do with the subjcct
under discussion. There
is something impressive in Plaggemeyer's peculiar
manner of "talking" to an
audience, which is far more effective than much that is
miscalled oratory.
Chas. A. Markell, Jr., was the second man on the
affirmative. The continuity of his arguments was broken several times
by repetitions caused by for-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

getfulness, and his hearers found difficulty in following him. It is possible that
some of his arguments were sound, but he did not succeed in impressing them
Upon his audience.
Solomon Blum followed Markell. He gave evidence of an ability to do
better work than he did. Blum seemed to think that the distinguished judges
of the debate are in the habit of frequenting the galleries of theatres. Much of
his•speech was a histrionic effort for the "gods." It is very good to be sarcastic, but the value of sarcasm is in inverse ratio to its abundance; it is very
good to ask oratorical questions, but, as the Germans say, "zu viel is/ ungesztnd." Blum should not have strived openly for effect so much, for at his
best he certainly is a good speaker, has a flexible, open, full voice. His arguments were better than his colleague's, and, altogether, he was equal to the high
standard set by his co-workers in the evening's debate.
Harvey B. Stone summed up for the affirmative, and did it well. He is a
convincing speaker, natural, and at home. Like Blum, however, he was at
times too clever; and allowed his propensity to "get on" with the audience to
run ahead of his reason. Most of his speech was extemporaneous, and he
showed ability to think quickly and speak epigrammatically.
When G. D. Strayer arose to end the debate many points brought up by
the affirmative still remained unanswered. He answered most of them, and the
debate went to the juniors. Undoubtedly much that he said could have been
refuted by a following speaker, but this advantage always lies with the neg•
ative. Strayer made no attempt at oratory, and the effect that he produced was
almost entirely due to his arguments. He spoke plainly and clearly, and
showed a comprehensive grasp of the whole argument of the seniors. When he
finished speaking there was no doubt as to whom the debating trophy of 1902
would be awarded.
All the men showed the effects of good training by Dr. Lee and his assistants, Mr. French and Mr. Thomas, and the undergraduates can be satisfied
with the success of the affair.
The senior alternates were: Ross M. Diggs, S. Wolman, Wm. Kirk. Advisers: J. G. Campbell, W. H. Koppelman, Chas. A. Myers. Junior alternates were: A. R. V. Dochez, J. B. G. Cutis, Jr. J. M. Coombs. Advisers:
H, K. Tootle, T. W. Glocker, C. H. Stubenrauch. The judges were: Freshman Public Speaking Contest, Messrs. Richard H. Bayard, Herbert M. Brune,
B. Howard Haman. Of debate: Hon. Henry D Harlan, Messrs. Wm. S.
Bryan, Jr., Alfred S. Niles. Chairman of Arrangement Committee: Aubrey
Pearre, Jr., '02. Chief usher: E. B. Beasley, '02.

In the new Harvard catalogue we read: "A student completing in three
years the requisite number of courses with such grade as may entitle him to
'curn laude,' may, on petitioning, be recommended for the degree at the end of
his third year, and obtain leave of absence until the time when the degree may
actually be conferred." Princeton is also providing for an A. B. after three
years of study.

N the article on the fifth public interclass debate the writer, who is a member

3

of one of the earlier teams, well says that the success of these debates
reached their summit two or three years ago, and that this year's contest
was in every respect up to this height. Only those who have ever tried for a
position on the debating teams realize what the cost of this success is, how
strenuous are the efforts of the men trying for positions, how difficult the work of
Dr. Lee and his assistants. The men on the teams deserve congratulations for
the spirit they have shown, for without willingness on the part of the students
the affair could not be a success; but to Dr. Lee, as originator of the plan of
inter class debates, belongs the chief credit. The advantages of these annual
affairs as a means of communication between the city and the college have been
harped upon till the string is almost broken. This year the especial interest in
the debate lay in the fact that it served as a trying-out for positions on the college team to represent Hopkins in her first intercollegiate debate, to be held
against the undergraduates of the University of North Carolina, Thursday of
this week.
This debate is really the culmination of the five years work in the college
House and Senate, and is possibly regarded as one of the most important dates
in the undergraduate calendar for 1902. The men who tried for positions exerted every effort, and the two men finally selected represent the best in the

THE NEWS—LETTER.

7

Hopkins undergraduate body. North Carolina has always held a high record
in the matter of good speakers, and it is reasonable to suppose that the men
she sends against Hopkins will be her best. Consequently the debate should
be a close fight, in which the better team will win. The Hopkins team is going
in with well-founded confidence, but, win or lose, the spirit which prompted our
men to work will still be there, and if we lose, we will acknowledge defeat at
the hands of superiors with the same spirit with which we would celebrate
victory.
T Hopkins, as every one knows, the number of undergraduate students
reaches the sublime heights of one hundred and sixty six (166). Of these
men, about thirty are engaged in lacrosse, twenty or more in base ball,
fifteen or twenty in track and field work, and the same number tried for the
'varsity football team last fall. On the musical clubs are about twenty-five un
dergraduates, twenty two men are interested in Hullabaloo and NEWS-LETTER
work, and each year there are some twenty five candidates for positions on the
debating teams. Altogether this means that on the average every man at Hopkins is interested in some branch outside his study, even though a scholastic
average of two and a half is required before participation in these enterprises is
allowed. With these figures staring one in the face no one can say that Hopkins spirit is low. There is plenty of spirit here, and plenty of life. A man
undergoes the same experiences of life whether he walks on a sixteen acre
campus or crosses the cobbles of a narrow street. With such a condition of
affairs why do we not have some Hopkins stories? The background is excellent; incidents which will work up into good short stories are continually arising. A retrospect into the history of some of our recently graduated class will
reveal plot and counterplot, which in stirring dramatic force excells the wildest
melodramas. There can be no doubt that the material is on hand for Hopkins
short stories. So far what has not been in evidence is Hopkins men to write
the stories. The NEWS LETTER'S present policy of publishing short stories
could take no better form than in stories of the deeds of Hopkins' own sons.
We hope that men who call write will take this matter in hand, and possibly
we may soon be able to give to the reading public a collection of short stories.

4

HE Musical Clubs desire to extend their thanks, through the columns of
the NEWS LETTER, to all those members of the Faculty and student body
who by their large attendance made the Baltimore Concert such a success.
The encouragement of a crowded house doubly recompensed the members, leaders and managers for their work and trouble; for the shekels gathered in were
so many that not only have all the Club debts been paid off, but a substantial
surplus remains towards defraying the expenses of the Easter trip to Old Point.
If this in turn is successful, it will again be the pleasure of the Clubs to aid
some department of athletics as they did last year, when, in addition to the
athletic concert, $100.00 was given to the training table fund.

e

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ITH its last issue, the special celebration number, the NEws-Livrrim
reached the highest point of its circulation. A great many extra copies
were sold to those who wished to preserve a compact account of the exercises. These have gone in all directions, one as far as the Philippines Islands.
This climax of circulation and expansion, however, comes at a time when the
staff is about to be weakened by the loss of some of its members. The paper
will, as usual, be handed over to the Junior class at Easter, and the resignation
at that time of four Senior members of the board will leave as many positions
vacant.
In the competition which has just closed, some very creditable work was
done, and several of those who were passed over can continue their efforts with a
good chance of success. But it must not be thought that the opportunity of
securing a place is in any way narrowed down. We would like to hear from
any and every student who has an idea for a humorous sketch, a poem, a story,
or who can furnish news notes of alumni, etc., or wishes to take a trial assignment to cover some college event.

THE CONCERT OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
RIDAY evening, February 14, the annual concert of the t iopkins Musical
Clubs was held at Lehmann'g Hall. The hall was splendidly filled, even
the gallery being crowded. Over a hundred girls from the Woman's Col
lege, delegations from various schools, along with many of this season's debutantes and next year's, were in the audience. The walls were well decorated,
but not quite as attractively as the auditorium itself.
Everything went off as smoothly as could be desired. The program opened
with the Glee Club singing The 'Varsity Ode, the soberness of which was relieved by the encore which they sang. Then came ''The Mosquito Parade,"
by the Banjo Club, followed by the "Invincible Eagle," played by the Mandolin Club. Mr. Gilman, of the Medical School, then sang three very effective
numbers. He has a splendid, round, full voice, well under control. It lacks
only dramatic fire. His song of the "Blacksmith" was by far the best he
rendered. Mr. Edgeworth Smith's "The Ragged Raglan," played in a dashing
manner by the Banjo Club, won great applause, as did J. H. Iiager's "1902
Medley." Then Mr. Edgeworth Smith (lid a difficult turn with the banjo.
Mr. Atkinson's coon songs seemed to please everybody. The program ended
with W. B. Carver's 'Alma rater in Dixie Land," which is not as affective by
the clubs as on the field.
From a musical standpoint, the Banjo Club deserves the most praise. They
have been well trained, and seemed to understand and to have confidence in
their leader. They played with great spirit and dash. The volume and roundness of their tone was always good. The Mandolin Club played fairly well,
but at times they were lacking in volume and unity of tone. The Glee Club is
in had need of more tenors. There was a heavy strain on that "part of the club
which caused too great an effort, the high notes being left almost entirely to
Mr. Carver.
All in all it was a most satisfactory concert. The management and the
players are to be congratulated upon the smoothness with which everything
was handled.

at

was pulmonary trouble, from which he suffered for several years.
At a recent meeting of the School Board of Baltimore, Dr. Gilman tendered
his resignation as commissioner. His resignation was accepted with regrets,
and thanks for his many services rendered.
Mr. Clayton Colman Hall, LL. B., of the Baltimore bar, is delivering a
course of six lectures in McCoy Hall, on the general subject of the "Lords
Baltimore and the Maryland Palatinate." These lectures are given through
the generosity of the Maryland Society of the "Colonial Dames of America."

In

The eleventh annual meeting of the Northwestern Alumni Association was
held in Chicago on the night of February 28th. Dr. Remsen was the guest of
honor. The association has issued a memorial addressed to the president and
the board of trustees of the University on the completion of the quarter century
of the University, and of the development during that period.
The March number of Scribner's Magazine contains the first of Dr. Gilman's recollections of the last quarter century. In the article which is entitled
"The Launching of a University," Dr. Gilman gives some entertaining
reminiscences of the early days of the University, and of the men who were
identified with him in those days. Especially interesting is his account of how
it happened that the late Professor Rowland, at that time but twenty-eight years
old, and an assistant instructor in the Reusselear Polytechnic Institute, was
selected for the chair of physics.
President Remsen was in Chicago during the week of February 24, attending a meeting of "The Association of American Universities." The object of the
association, as Dr. Remsen explained, is merely to discuss important questions
of education. The discussion at the Chicago meeting was on the requirement
of a dissertation for the degree of doctor of philosophy, and the additional requisite that his treatise be published. This is a topic of special interest to Hopkins men, since the University has always required that the candidate for a
doctor's degree have his thesis printed.
While in Chicago Dr. Remsen was the guest at a number of social events
Dr. Henry Wood was in Cambridge last week attending a reception given
to Prince Henry.

10

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Professor A. M. Soho, Ph. D., of the University in 1898, has assumed his
duties in the Latin and French department of the Baltimore City College. Before coming to the City College, Dr. Soho was at St. John's College, Annapolis.
The undergraduate students of the geological department spent Saturday,
March 1, at Chesapeake Beach collecting miocene and paleozoic fossil. Mr. R.
0. Miller had charge of the party.
Mr. Albert Eugene Curdy, fellow in Romance languages, has been appointed instructor in French in the academic department of Yale University.
Mr. Curdy, who received his A. B. at the University of Kansas, has been a
graduate student at Hopkins for several years. He will receive the degree of
doctor of philosophy this Spring, and in September will take up his duties at
Yale.
The trustees of the University have voted the degree of Bachelor of Arts to
Messrs. R. S. Duck and W. Hall Harris, Jr., both having successfully corn
pleted the requisite courses of study.
Miss Susan E. Blow, of St. Louis, delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall on
the night of the 4th, on "The Educational Value of the Kindergarten, and Its
Place in the Public Schools." At the close of Miss Blow's lecture, Superintendent of Public Instruction J. H. Van Sickle gave a short account of the
public school kindergarten. This lecture was provided for by the Kindergarten
Training School of the Baltimore Association.
Professor Francis W. Kelsey, of the University of Michigan, will deliver
an illustrated lecture upon "Ten Years of Excavation at Pompeii, 1892-1900,"
in McCoy Hall, on Saturday, March 15. The lecture will be given under the
auspices of the Baltimore Society of the Archaeological Institute of America.
On the afternoon of Friday, March 14, Professor Leopold Mabillean, corresponding member of the Institute of France and director of the "Musee Social
de Paris," will deliver a lecture upon "L'Ouvrier Francais." The lecture will
be in French.
In the Woman's College kalends, describing a reception of the Washington
alumnae on January 21, we find the following: "Representation from Johns
Hopkins, without which no Woman's College reception could be a success, was
on this occasion made by Christopher Clark, J. H. U., 1900."
The Senior Class meets Friday night at the Hotel St. James for its annual
class banquet. What little is known of the arrangements and toasts points to
a great old time. Mr. Lyman C. Murphy was elected by the class in a general
meeting, to hold the baton of master of the toasts, and it is expected that his
reign will be one long jollity. The committees in charge consist of: Arrangements, Thomas C. Pinkerton, E. B. Beasley, Henry Beeuwkees; Speeches,
John G. Campbell, Chas. A. Myers, Ogle Marbury.
The members of the Junior Class debating team entertained Dr. Guy
Carleton Lee at dinner at the Hotel Marlborough on the night of the 6th.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

11

LACROSSE.
INCE the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER containing athletic news, nearly
four weeks ago, practice has been going on regularly, and the men have
been steadily improving. They now play as if they were beginning to
see through the game, and are doing more of the quick passing which, heretofore, has helped Hopkins to outplay weight.
Among those who have played before this year, but not on the team, Sidney Smith, Bird, Bryan, and Custis are forging to the front. Smith has been
playing a good, heady game on the attack; but during the last week he has been
a little off color. Bird and Bryan are both making a good showing, but still
have something to learn. The former's fault seems to be the lack of clean stickwork; his idea of team work is good, but owing to a hitch in his passing he cannot always carry it out. This trouble ought to be adjusted by practice. As for
Bryan, he shows good ability to catch and pass the ball when it is put to him;
but he does not fight hard enough to get it himself. Custis is daily improving
in his stickwork, but has not reached the perfection mark yet. He is being
tried out on the defense. It is hoped that he will make a better showing when
out-door practice begins.
Of the new men at the game, S. Pearre, Matthai, and Blanck are the only
ones in the race, Pearre has been alternating between in and out-home and
ought to make a good one next year. He is playing a clever game. Much the
same may be said about Matthai; he has been playing at centre and third attack. Blanck, our foot ball captain, is making a creditable showing at close
defense. He is playing a hard and heady game; and if he can bring his stickwork up to the required standard, he will probably help Hopkins in her games

A

this year.
The old men all seem to be improving, but they never do play their game
until they get out of doors. The Cage seems to lower their lacrosse ability.
The great thing which worries the coaches now is to find the combination
which will make the best team They have plenty of material for the attack
and the defense, but as always they are a little shy on good goal-keepers.
Briscoe, who played in many of the games last year, has been out as often as
his work at the Medical School will permit. Pets and P. Straus are both nervy
players, but lack experience. Captain Schmeisser, who played goal until late
in his freshman year, has again been trying to get his eye in so that he may be
able, in case of necessity, to fill the position.

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Although it is still very early and always dangerous to make predictions,
especially when the men have had no outdoor practice, yet the NEWS LETER
would like to predict that the team will be selected from the following men:
Abercrombie, W. Sehmeisser, Straus, B. Bernheitn, P. Bernheim, Briscoe,
Putts, E. Schtneisser, Tough, Sayler, Bird, Smith, Bryan, Custis, Blanck,
Pearre, Pels, P. Straus, Matthai.
As soon as the snow gets off the ground, the team will begin to practice at
the American League Park. Here the real practice commences, the practice
that will mean the winning or losing of the championship. It is hoped that the
attendance will be large enough to give the "'Varsity" a good scrub to play
against each day.

BASE BALL.

t

HE response to the call for candidates made on February 15 has been so
hearty and so well sustained that the success of the team promises to be a
question of degree. On Tuesdays Thursdays, and Saturdays the squad
has practice, and on no afternoon have less than fifteen men been out, the number being frequently twenty or more. It seems absurd that Hopkins cannot
now equal her former reputation in base ball. This inability appears about to
be ended. The season will soon begin, and sp far there has been no flagging
in interest. The outcome of the whole movement now lies almost altogether
with the men themselves. Heretofore, lack of grounds has proved a stumbling
block; but this year outdoor grounds and all other essential conditions have
been provided for. The opportunity is certainly excellent.
The team is fortunate in having as manager Mr. Maurice Lazenby, of the
Medical School, who was elected at the first meeting of the candidates. Mr.
Lazenby has been active for several years in promoting the success of athletics
at Hopkins, and his service in this new cause goes to swell a long list of former
services. He has named, as his assistants, L. M. R. Willis and J N. Numsen, '04.
As for the men themselves, nothing need be feared, except possible listlessness. There is no sign of this at present. Work in the Cage consists of
handling batted balls, of getting arms into condition, and of batting. This last
exercise should have telling effect. No college in the country has such a place
to train batters. The infield positions are aspired to by as many as ten men,
and there are tried men for the outfield The pitchers are in good condition,
and give promise of making conquests. Both of them have good curves, with
speed and control.
The schedule, as partially arranged, includes games at home with Princeton and Georgetown, and abroad with Rock Hill, the Naval Cadets (probably),
Maryland Agricultural College, and Western Maryland College.
In view of this auspicious beginning, every lover of college sport at Hopkins
ought to be loyal and stand behind the new effort, so that it does not fail. Let
the players be encouraged, the games patronized, and above all let there be a

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

general participation in the game itself. The best team will come from many
candidates. When out-door work begins, it will he necessary to have two
teams. This is imperative. There is work for all. The undergraduates, particularly, should remember that upon them depends largely the fate of the sport
in the years'to follow. Slumbering stars, awake! there's a task that is worthy
of your toil.
ATHLETIC NOTES.
It has not been fully decided whether any men will go to the games given
by Company D, First Regiment, National Guard of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, on March 15, but some of our athletes will probably go.
The Central Y. M. C. A. games at the Y. M. C. A. Gymnasium, corner
Charles and Saratoga, on March 29, will also attract a few of the wearers of
black and blue.
Final arrangements have been completed for the use of the American
League Park by our lacrosse and base ball teams. This is a great thing for
these teams, as a supplement to the Cage practice, and its benefits will doubtless be shown in the games. All the games in both the lacrosse and base ball
schedule will be played at the American League Parke

BALTIMORE, MARCH 7, 1902.

The Johns Hopkins University Athletic Association begs leave to tender
you an invitation to their Annual Indoor Track and Field Meet, to be held, in
the Training "Cage," Howard Street, North, on the evening of Saturday, April
the fifth, at eight o'clock.
The following events are submitted for your consideration:
Handicaps:--30 yards dash; 30 yards dash for Preparatory Schools; 440
yards run: 880 yards run; 1 mile run; running high jump; putting 16 lb. shot.
Scratch-440 yards run for Preparatory Schools.
Fencing—Foils. Open to Maryland.
Relay races for Universities, Colleges, Schools, and Athletic Clubs.
Your attention is called to a decided and most important innovation in
indoor athletics, that we are able to present to those desirous of entering: that
of beintz able to run on a cinder track and on an earthen floor for field events;
thus allowing competitors to wear regular outdoor or long-spiked shoes.
Doubtless, this will be fully appreciated by those who are familiar with the
customary board -floor tracks.
The track will be about ten feet wide, and eighteen laps to the mile, completely banked at the turns.
The winners of first, second and third places, in each event, except the
relays, will receive prizes. In the relay races, individual prizes will be given,

Professor G. W. Russel died at his home in Roanoke, Va., on February 25.
Professor Russel was a graduate student in chemistry at the University from
'97 to '99, and at the time of his death was professor of sciences at the Roanoke
High School.

THE SENIOR CLUB.

t/

o the junior class is due the credit of founding the first undergraduate club
ever instituted at the Johns Hopkins For several weeks past the ten
men who conceived the plan have been quietly engaged in making the
necessary arrangements. The name—The Senior Club—has been decided upon,
a constitution has been drawn up, and all that remains to make the the project
a reality is to select suitable quarters and begin the collection of dues. Every
1903 man has exhibited the usual class spirit by signing a slip stating that he
will contribute financially and otherwise to the success of the new organization,
and failure is out of the question. The club is to be strictly a senior institution
as the name signifies, and will be kept up each year by the graduating class at
the University. Those who take degrees will be numbered thereafter among
its honorary members.
It is not improbable that the idea was suggested by President Remsen's
short address at the annual athletic feed. In speaking of student organizations
for the promotion of social intercourse he referred in the highest terms to the
Houston Club of the University of Pennsylvania and expressed a wish that
Hopkins might, sometime, have a similar organization.
To those who have visited the magnificent quarters of the students at
Pennsylvania, our chances for such a club in the near future seem very slight.
Everything has a beginning, however, and some day may find the Senior Club
handsomely located among the many imposing buildings at Homewood.
In recognition of their work, the junior class elected the ten men, who have
crystallized the plans as members of the first board of governors. They will
assume active control next October, when the club will begin its existence.
They are: H. W Plaggemeyer, R. C. Hoffman, Jr., J. A. Addison, secretary;
H. K. Tootle, treasurer; R. C. Pagon, G. D. Strayer, J. T. Smith, C. M.
Riley, J. C. Hildt, and P. R. Straus.

•

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

VERBICIDE!
Has the Thought Ever Struck You:
That a freshman can be told by his temperature, a junior by his humidity,
and a senior by his specific gravity;—
That science has invented no instrument delicate enough to fathom a post
graduate;—
That he is apt to be six feet tall, two feet wide, and one foot deep;—
That Carnegie Institute will be a valuable adjunct to the J. H. U.;—
That the two institutions may some day be connected by a boulevard;—
That it is to be hoped that there will be no mortgage on this end;—
That the magnificent property recently given our University is very hilly;—
That professors and students will have their ups and downs;—
That the people of Luzon and Samar are slow to love Uncle Sam;—
That someone must have told them we eat philopenas;—
That if American soldiers would give them a sample of our new college
yells, they would willingly surrender or die;—
That the world revolves on its axis;—
That for this reason everything is sure to come our way;—
That if we could travel eastward at the rate of about 1,000 miles an hour,
the sun would not go down;—
That the same day would continue so long as we traveled,—
That if we started on Sunday our rest day would last until we rested, and
no longer.
H. L. LLOYD, '04.
THE INTERCOLLEGIATE DEBATE.
FTER a year of hard work, the first intercollegiate debate in which Hopkins has ever participated takes place on Thursday of this week • The
two delegates from the University of North Carolina, Messrs. Williams,
'02, and Stearn, '02, are supposed to be from the best in the undergraduate
body, and our two men, Harry Plaggemeyer, '03, and H. B. Stone, '02, were
only chosen at the last moment. The trust question will be debated, North
Carolina defending the trust. The reception committee, which has succeeded
in making Baltimore comfortable for our guests, is composed of Ross M. Diggs,
chairman; Harvey B. Stone, John G. Campbell, Robinson C. Pagon, R. C.
Hoffman, Jr. Several of the Fraternities have kindly offered to quarter the
North Carolina speakers.

4

The March number of the Critic contains two very clever sketches by Mr.
Ira M. Remsen, '97, mention of whose growing reputation has already been
made in these columns.

THE NEWSLETTER.

16

A MAGAZINE OF COLLEGE SPORTS.
ILLIAM B. DWIGHT (Yale '54) expects to fill a long felt want in the
college world by publishing a monthly magazine devoted exclusively
to college sports. The magazine will be known as the "Intercollegiate
News." Mr. Dwight, the editor, needs no introduction to those who are
interested in athletics, and his name at the head of the enterprise forecasts the
success that justly awaits such a publication.
Associate-editors are being secured in all the colleges so that the editor
will be in touch with collegiate conditions and be able to furnish up to date
news. Mr. W. B. Hill, manager of last season's foot ball team, will have
charge of the Hopkins correspondence.
The magazine will contain timely articles on all important questions of
athletics, and will prove of great value in making every one acquainted with
the conditions existing at the different colleges. This will be particularly valuable to Hopkins, since it furnishes an organ wherein we can explain the peculiar situation in which we are placed athletically.

As the engine clanked away, the ruddy-faced young man paused on his
way up the next hill, and looked hack at the station. He saw the usual group
of jean-clad mountain people and ragged darkies all staring at the half-dozen
picturesque revenue officers as they filed along. 'Gee!" he said," if I had a
pair of hoots to stick my breeches in, I would do, myself. Wide black hat—
gun—blue coat." Returned and briskly went at the steep hill.
He had topped the rise, when he was passed by a lanky, chalk-faced
mountaineer, riding a scraggy mule, who had just left the station. The man
looked the picture of indolence and apathy. He lolled back on the saddle, his
ungainly legs swinging in time to the mule's amble, his bridle-hand resting on
the big saddle horn. He rounded a curve a hundred yards ahead. The next
moment the walker heard a sharp crack, and the irregular beat of galloping
hoofs. He sprang upon a stump. Through a gap in the trees he caught a
glimpse of the mule tearing by in a clumsy run, urged on by the vigorous
blows and kicks of its rider.
Wondering a little, the young man continued on his ascending path. Soon
he left behind the last outpost of the little settlement, and the world became a
vast slope of green, upward-rolling mountain spurs. The pines soughed in the
balmy wind, and breathed down to him a pungent fragrance. He cast a last
look behind him at the tiny village lying below. Then he turned, and plunged
into the heart of the ever ascending forest.
II

Green corn whiskey,fresh distilled, is no gentle drink; yet the gray-bearded
old moonshiner at one draught took nearly the whole glassful.
"Hit air a main good bead," he chuckled, stirring up with a grimy talon a
multitude of tiny bubbles in the finger's-breadth of liquor that remained. These
betokened that there had been an unusually potent "mash," or mixture of corn
and water left in a barrel to ferment before distillation.
The old man picked up a bucket and went to the "worm" to get a fresh
supply of whiskey. This clumsy, big retort, with its coil of copper pipe, nearly
filled the little mud-chinked log cabin. Beside it, a stream of water trickled
along a rude shute into a trough. The distiller picked up an earthenware jug
that was lying by; and, having pulled out its corn-cob stopper, he skillfully proceeded, without the aid of a funnel, to decant into it the whiskey from his pail.
The crouching old man, with his heavy brows and sharp eyes, was a naturally dignified and commanding figure. The effect, however, was hampered by
his torn hickory shirt, crossed by a single suspender, and somewhat imperfectly
connected with his butternut jeans; while his spreading brogans were slit open
on each side, for the better accomodation of his "footso's." This laxity of dress
indicated a corresponding freedom of thought and action. It hinted at the
difficulties in store for any Professor of Governmental Theory, let us say, who
should undertake to show him how it was less lawful to distill his corn than to
grind it.

THE FIFTH PUBLIC DEBATE.
N striking contrast to the part the undergraduates played at the
celebration,
on February 21-22, was their role in the annual contest in public speak-

3

ing and debate held on Thursday, February 27. Phrases such as
tween 500 and 1,000 late ticket holders were turned away from the doors shortly
after eight o'clock," and "the debate this year, as usual, helped bring togethe
r
the people of the city and the college men" have become so commonplace in re.
porting our debates that it is best to immediately proceed to a discussion
of the
debate and contest themselves.
The Freshman speakers were all good, but only the prize winner, Licking,
was very good. He was the only speaker who had force, and being blessed
with a finely modulated voice, he was able to hold the attention of his audience.
Humrichhouse had the tendency to let his eyes wander into celestia
l regions
while he was talking in tragic depths of Schley's attack on Santiago. Schapiro had disadvantages to overcome, which, when taken into conside
ration,
cause us to call his effort a strong one. But with Schapiro as with Humric
hhouse the performance idea was too powerful; any one could tell that
the men
were reciting, and not giving their own speeches. All three speakers
made
much better use of gesture than is usual among speakers from the first
year
class.
In the debate, the seniors were fairly out-classed. Excuses are the
easiest
things in the world to find, but one reason for the defeat of
the seniors is so
powerfully apparent that it would be foolish to delve into the
fires and cons of
the matter. The junior team was manifestly superior to that
of the seniors. It
is true that the juniors had the negative of the question [Resolv
ed that: "Trusts
threaten the future welfare of the United States,1 and that
they had the advantage of having the last speech, but their speakers were so
superior in effective delivery to the seniors that even with an equality of argume
nt the debate
would probably have gone to them, Even as it was they
slightly surpassed
their opponents in weight of argument.
Fred. L. (;uggenheirner, who was the first speaker for
the affirmative, tried
to make a dramatic recital out of an essay. Especially
was his dramatic affectation noticed in the wild use he made of his hands.
Otherwise he was excellent. His voice could be heard all over the hall,
his enunciation was distinct, and he brought out the connection between his argume
nts as well as his
speech allowed.
Harry Plaggemeyer led for the negative and, with
his colleague Blum, won
the honors of the evening. Intense, and thoroughly
interested in his subject,
he doubtless made a great many .people think he was
making points, whereas
his speech had hardly anything to do with the subjcct
under discussion. There
is something impressive in Plaggemeyer's peculiar
manner of "talking" to an
audience, which is far more effective than much that is
miscalled oratory.
Chas. A. Markell, Jr., was the second man on the
affirmative. The continuity of his arguments was broken several times
by repetitions caused by for-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

getfulness, and his hearers found difficulty in following him. It is possible that
some of his arguments were sound, but he did not succeed in impressing them
Upon his audience.
Solomon Blum followed Markell. He gave evidence of an ability to do
better work than he did. Blum seemed to think that the distinguished judges
of the debate are in the habit of frequenting the galleries of theatres. Much of
his•speech was a histrionic effort for the "gods." It is very good to be sarcastic, but the value of sarcasm is in inverse ratio to its abundance; it is very
good to ask oratorical questions, but, as the Germans say, "zu viel is/ ungesztnd." Blum should not have strived openly for effect so much, for at his
best he certainly is a good speaker, has a flexible, open, full voice. His arguments were better than his colleague's, and, altogether, he was equal to the high
standard set by his co-workers in the evening's debate.
Harvey B. Stone summed up for the affirmative, and did it well. He is a
convincing speaker, natural, and at home. Like Blum, however, he was at
times too clever; and allowed his propensity to "get on" with the audience to
run ahead of his reason. Most of his speech was extemporaneous, and he
showed ability to think quickly and speak epigrammatically.
When G. D. Strayer arose to end the debate many points brought up by
the affirmative still remained unanswered. He answered most of them, and the
debate went to the juniors. Undoubtedly much that he said could have been
refuted by a following speaker, but this advantage always lies with the neg•
ative. Strayer made no attempt at oratory, and the effect that he produced was
almost entirely due to his arguments. He spoke plainly and clearly, and
showed a comprehensive grasp of the whole argument of the seniors. When he
finished speaking there was no doubt as to whom the debating trophy of 1902
would be awarded.
All the men showed the effects of good training by Dr. Lee and his assistants, Mr. French and Mr. Thomas, and the undergraduates can be satisfied
with the success of the affair.

N the article on the fifth public interclass debate the writer, who is a member

3

of one of the earlier teams, well says that the success of these debates
reached their summit two or three years ago, and that this year's contest
was in every respect up to this height. Only those who have ever tried for a
position on the debating teams realize what the cost of this success is, how
strenuous are the efforts of the men trying for positions, how difficult the work of
Dr. Lee and his assistants. The men on the teams deserve congratulations for
the spirit they have shown, for without willingness on the part of the students
the affair could not be a success; but to Dr. Lee, as originator of the plan of
inter class debates, belongs the chief credit. The advantages of these annual
affairs as a means of communication between the city and the college have been
harped upon till the string is almost broken. This year the especial interest in
the debate lay in the fact that it served as a trying-out for positions on the college team to represent Hopkins in her first intercollegiate debate, to be held
against the undergraduates of the University of North Carolina, Thursday of
this week.
This debate is really the culmination of the five years work in the college
House and Senate, and is possibly regarded as one of the most important dates
in the undergraduate calendar for 1902. The men who tried for positions exerted every effort, and the two men finally selected represent the best in the

THE NEWS—LETTER.

7

Hopkins undergraduate body. North Carolina has always held a high record
in the matter of good speakers, and it is reasonable to suppose that the men
she sends against Hopkins will be her best. Consequently the debate should
be a close fight, in which the better team will win. The Hopkins team is going
in with well-founded confidence, but, win or lose, the spirit which prompted our
men to work will still be there, and if we lose, we will acknowledge defeat at
the hands of superiors with the same spirit with which we would celebrate
victory.
T Hopkins, as every one knows, the number of undergraduate students
reaches the sublime heights of one hundred and sixty six (166). Of these
men, about thirty are engaged in lacrosse, twenty or more in base ball,
fifteen or twenty in track and field work, and the same number tried for the
'varsity football team last fall. On the musical clubs are about twenty-five un
dergraduates, twenty two men are interested in Hullabaloo and NEWS-LETTER
work, and each year there are some twenty five candidates for positions on the
debating teams. Altogether this means that on the average every man at Hopkins is interested in some branch outside his study, even though a scholastic
average of two and a half is required before participation in these enterprises is
allowed. With these figures staring one in the face no one can say that Hopkins spirit is low. There is plenty of spirit here, and plenty of life. A man
undergoes the same experiences of life whether he walks on a sixteen acre
campus or crosses the cobbles of a narrow street. With such a condition of
affairs why do we not have some Hopkins stories? The background is excellent; incidents which will work up into good short stories are continually arising. A retrospect into the history of some of our recently graduated class will
reveal plot and counterplot, which in stirring dramatic force excells the wildest
melodramas. There can be no doubt that the material is on hand for Hopkins
short stories. So far what has not been in evidence is Hopkins men to write
the stories. The NEWS LETTER'S present policy of publishing short stories
could take no better form than in stories of the deeds of Hopkins' own sons.
We hope that men who call write will take this matter in hand, and possibly
we may soon be able to give to the reading public a collection of short stories.

HE Musical Clubs desire to extend their thanks, through the columns of
the NEWS LETTER, to all those members of the Faculty and student body
who by their large attendance made the Baltimore Concert such a success.
The encouragement of a crowded house doubly recompensed the members, leaders and managers for their work and trouble; for the shekels gathered in were
so many that not only have all the Club debts been paid off, but a substantial
surplus remains towards defraying the expenses of the Easter trip to Old Point.
If this in turn is successful, it will again be the pleasure of the Clubs to aid
some department of athletics as they did last year, when, in addition to the
athletic concert, $100.00 was given to the training table fund.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ITH its last issue, the special celebration number, the NEws-Livrrim
reached the highest point of its circulation. A great many extra copies
were sold to those who wished to preserve a compact account of the exercises. These have gone in all directions, one as far as the Philippines Islands.
This climax of circulation and expansion, however, comes at a time when the
staff is about to be weakened by the loss of some of its members. The paper
will, as usual, be handed over to the Junior class at Easter, and the resignation
at that time of four Senior members of the board will leave as many positions
vacant.
In the competition which has just closed, some very creditable work was
done, and several of those who were passed over can continue their efforts with a
good chance of success. But it must not be thought that the opportunity of
securing a place is in any way narrowed down. We would like to hear from
any and every student who has an idea for a humorous sketch, a poem, a story,
or who can furnish news notes of alumni, etc., or wishes to take a trial assignment to cover some college event.

THE CONCERT OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
RIDAY evening, February 14, the annual concert of the t iopkins Musical
Clubs was held at Lehmann'g Hall. The hall was splendidly filled, even
the gallery being crowded. Over a hundred girls from the Woman's Col
lege, delegations from various schools, along with many of this season's debutantes and next year's, were in the audience. The walls were well decorated,
but not quite as attractively as the auditorium itself.
Everything went off as smoothly as could be desired. The program opened
with the Glee Club singing The 'Varsity Ode, the soberness of which was relieved by the encore which they sang. Then came ''The Mosquito Parade,"
by the Banjo Club, followed by the "Invincible Eagle," played by the Mandolin Club. Mr. Gilman, of the Medical School, then sang three very effective
numbers. He has a splendid, round, full voice, well under control. It lacks
only dramatic fire. His song of the "Blacksmith" was by far the best he
rendered. Mr. Edgeworth Smith's "The Ragged Raglan," played in a dashing
manner by the Banjo Club, won great applause, as did J. H. Iiager's "1902
Medley." Then Mr. Edgeworth Smith (lid a difficult turn with the banjo.
Mr. Atkinson's coon songs seemed to please everybody. The program ended
with W. B. Carver's 'Alma rater in Dixie Land," which is not as affective by
the clubs as on the field.
From a musical standpoint, the Banjo Club deserves the most praise. They
have been well trained, and seemed to understand and to have confidence in
their leader. They played with great spirit and dash. The volume and roundness of their tone was always good. The Mandolin Club played fairly well,
but at times they were lacking in volume and unity of tone. The Glee Club is
in had need of more tenors. There was a heavy strain on that "part of the club
which caused too great an effort, the high notes being left almost entirely to
Mr. Carver.
All in all it was a most satisfactory concert. The management and the
players are to be congratulated upon the smoothness with which everything
was handled.

At a recent meeting of the School Board of Baltimore, Dr. Gilman tendered
his resignation as commissioner. His resignation was accepted with regrets,
and thanks for his many services rendered.
Mr. Clayton Colman Hall, LL. B., of the Baltimore bar, is delivering a
course of six lectures in McCoy Hall, on the general subject of the "Lords
Baltimore and the Maryland Palatinate." These lectures are given through
the generosity of the Maryland Society of the "Colonial Dames of America."

In

The eleventh annual meeting of the Northwestern Alumni Association was
held in Chicago on the night of February 28th. Dr. Remsen was the guest of
honor. The association has issued a memorial addressed to the president and
the board of trustees of the University on the completion of the quarter century
of the University, and of the development during that period.
The March number of Scribner's Magazine contains the first of Dr. Gilman's recollections of the last quarter century. In the article which is entitled
"The Launching of a University," Dr. Gilman gives some entertaining
reminiscences of the early days of the University, and of the men who were
identified with him in those days. Especially interesting is his account of how
it happened that the late Professor Rowland, at that time but twenty-eight years
old, and an assistant instructor in the Reusselear Polytechnic Institute, was
selected for the chair of physics.
President Remsen was in Chicago during the week of February 24, attending a meeting of "The Association of American Universities." The object of the
association, as Dr. Remsen explained, is merely to discuss important questions
of education. The discussion at the Chicago meeting was on the requirement
of a dissertation for the degree of doctor of philosophy, and the additional requisite that his treatise be published. This is a topic of special interest to Hopkins men, since the University has always required that the candidate for a
doctor's degree have his thesis printed.
While in Chicago Dr. Remsen was the guest at a number of social events
Dr. Henry Wood was in Cambridge last week attending a reception given
to Prince Henry.

10

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Professor A. M. Soho, Ph. D., of the University in 1898, has assumed his
duties in the Latin and French department of the Baltimore City College. Before coming to the City College, Dr. Soho was at St. John's College, Annapolis.
The undergraduate students of the geological department spent Saturday,
March 1, at Chesapeake Beach collecting miocene and paleozoic fossil. Mr. R.
0. Miller had charge of the party.
Mr. Albert Eugene Curdy, fellow in Romance languages, has been appointed instructor in French in the academic department of Yale University.
Mr. Curdy, who received his A. B. at the University of Kansas, has been a
graduate student at Hopkins for several years. He will receive the degree of
doctor of philosophy this Spring, and in September will take up his duties at
Yale.
The trustees of the University have voted the degree of Bachelor of Arts to
Messrs. R. S. Duck and W. Hall Harris, Jr., both having successfully corn
pleted the requisite courses of study.
Miss Susan E. Blow, of St. Louis, delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall on
the night of the 4th, on "The Educational Value of the Kindergarten, and Its
Place in the Public Schools." At the close of Miss Blow's lecture, Superintendent of Public Instruction J. H. Van Sickle gave a short account of the
public school kindergarten. This lecture was provided for by the Kindergarten
Training School of the Baltimore Association.
Professor Francis W. Kelsey, of the University of Michigan, will deliver
an illustrated lecture upon "Ten Years of Excavation at Pompeii, 1892-1900,"
in McCoy Hall, on Saturday, March 15. The lecture will be given under the
auspices of the Baltimore Society of the Archaeological Institute of America.
On the afternoon of Friday, March 14, Professor Leopold Mabillean, corresponding member of the Institute of France and director of the "Musee Social
de Paris," will deliver a lecture upon "L'Ouvrier Francais." The lecture will
be in French.
In the Woman's College kalends, describing a reception of the Washington
alumnae on January 21, we find the following: "Representation from Johns
Hopkins, without which no Woman's College reception could be a success, was
on this occasion made by Christopher Clark, J. H. U., 1900."
The Senior Class meets Friday night at the Hotel St. James for its annual
class banquet. What little is known of the arrangements and toasts points to
a great old time. Mr. Lyman C. Murphy was elected by the class in a general
meeting, to hold the baton of master of the toasts, and it is expected that his
reign will be one long jollity. The committees in charge consist of: Arrangements, Thomas C. Pinkerton, E. B. Beasley, Henry Beeuwkees; Speeches,
John G. Campbell, Chas. A. Myers, Ogle Marbury.
The members of the Junior Class debating team entertained Dr. Guy
Carleton Lee at dinner at the Hotel Marlborough on the night of the 6th.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

11

LACROSSE.
INCE the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER containing athletic news, nearly
four weeks ago, practice has been going on regularly, and the men have
been steadily improving. They now play as if they were beginning to
see through the game, and are doing more of the quick passing which, heretofore, has helped Hopkins to outplay weight.
Among those who have played before this year, but not on the team, Sidney Smith, Bird, Bryan, and Custis are forging to the front. Smith has been
playing a good, heady game on the attack; but during the last week he has been
a little off color. Bird and Bryan are both making a good showing, but still
have something to learn. The former's fault seems to be the lack of clean stickwork; his idea of team work is good, but owing to a hitch in his passing he cannot always carry it out. This trouble ought to be adjusted by practice. As for
Bryan, he shows good ability to catch and pass the ball when it is put to him;
but he does not fight hard enough to get it himself. Custis is daily improving
in his stickwork, but has not reached the perfection mark yet. He is being
tried out on the defense. It is hoped that he will make a better showing when
out-door practice begins.
Of the new men at the game, S. Pearre, Matthai, and Blanck are the only
ones in the race, Pearre has been alternating between in and out-home and
ought to make a good one next year. He is playing a clever game. Much the
same may be said about Matthai; he has been playing at centre and third attack. Blanck, our foot ball captain, is making a creditable showing at close
defense. He is playing a hard and heady game; and if he can bring his stickwork up to the required standard, he will probably help Hopkins in her games

A

this year.
The old men all seem to be improving, but they never do play their game
until they get out of doors. The Cage seems to lower their lacrosse ability.
The great thing which worries the coaches now is to find the combination
which will make the best team They have plenty of material for the attack
and the defense, but as always they are a little shy on good goal-keepers.
Briscoe, who played in many of the games last year, has been out as often as
his work at the Medical School will permit. Pets and P. Straus are both nervy
players, but lack experience. Captain Schmeisser, who played goal until late
in his freshman year, has again been trying to get his eye in so that he may be
able, in case of necessity, to fill the position.

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Although it is still very early and always dangerous to make predictions,
especially when the men have had no outdoor practice, yet the NEWS LETER
would like to predict that the team will be selected from the following men:
Abercrombie, W. Sehmeisser, Straus, B. Bernheitn, P. Bernheim, Briscoe,
Putts, E. Schtneisser, Tough, Sayler, Bird, Smith, Bryan, Custis, Blanck,
Pearre, Pels, P. Straus, Matthai.
As soon as the snow gets off the ground, the team will begin to practice at
the American League Park. Here the real practice commences, the practice
that will mean the winning or losing of the championship. It is hoped that the
attendance will be large enough to give the "'Varsity" a good scrub to play
against each day.

BASE BALL.

t

HE response to the call for candidates made on February 15 has been so
hearty and so well sustained that the success of the team promises to be a
question of degree. On Tuesdays Thursdays, and Saturdays the squad
has practice, and on no afternoon have less than fifteen men been out, the number being frequently twenty or more. It seems absurd that Hopkins cannot
now equal her former reputation in base ball. This inability appears about to
be ended. The season will soon begin, and sp far there has been no flagging
in interest. The outcome of the whole movement now lies almost altogether
with the men themselves. Heretofore, lack of grounds has proved a stumbling
block; but this year outdoor grounds and all other essential conditions have
been provided for. The opportunity is certainly excellent.
The team is fortunate in having as manager Mr. Maurice Lazenby, of the
Medical School, who was elected at the first meeting of the candidates. Mr.
Lazenby has been active for several years in promoting the success of athletics
at Hopkins, and his service in this new cause goes to swell a long list of former
services. He has named, as his assistants, L. M. R. Willis and J N. Numsen, '04.
As for the men themselves, nothing need be feared, except possible listlessness. There is no sign of this at present. Work in the Cage consists of
handling batted balls, of getting arms into condition, and of batting. This last
exercise should have telling effect. No college in the country has such a place
to train batters. The infield positions are aspired to by as many as ten men,
and there are tried men for the outfield The pitchers are in good condition,
and give promise of making conquests. Both of them have good curves, with
speed and control.
The schedule, as partially arranged, includes games at home with Princeton and Georgetown, and abroad with Rock Hill, the Naval Cadets (probably),
Maryland Agricultural College, and Western Maryland College.
In view of this auspicious beginning, every lover of college sport at Hopkins
ought to be loyal and stand behind the new effort, so that it does not fail. Let
the players be encouraged, the games patronized, and above all let there be a

THE NEWS—LETTER.

general participation in the game itself. The best team will come from many
candidates. When out-door work begins, it will he necessary to have two
teams. This is imperative. There is work for all. The undergraduates, particularly, should remember that upon them depends largely the fate of the sport
in the years'to follow. Slumbering stars, awake! there's a task that is worthy
of your toil.

The Johns Hopkins University Athletic Association begs leave to tender
you an invitation to their Annual Indoor Track and Field Meet, to be held, in
the Training "Cage," Howard Street, North, on the evening of Saturday, April
the fifth, at eight o'clock.
The following events are submitted for your consideration:
Handicaps:--30 yards dash; 30 yards dash for Preparatory Schools; 440
yards run: 880 yards run; 1 mile run; running high jump; putting 16 lb. shot.
Scratch-440 yards run for Preparatory Schools.
Fencing—Foils. Open to Maryland.
Relay races for Universities, Colleges, Schools, and Athletic Clubs.
Your attention is called to a decided and most important innovation in
indoor athletics, that we are able to present to those desirous of entering: that
of beintz able to run on a cinder track and on an earthen floor for field events;
thus allowing competitors to wear regular outdoor or long-spiked shoes.
Doubtless, this will be fully appreciated by those who are familiar with the
customary board -floor tracks.
The track will be about ten feet wide, and eighteen laps to the mile, completely banked at the turns.
The winners of first, second and third places, in each event, except the
relays, will receive prizes. In the relay races, individual prizes will be given,

Professor G. W. Russel died at his home in Roanoke, Va., on February 25.
Professor Russel was a graduate student in chemistry at the University from
'97 to '99, and at the time of his death was professor of sciences at the Roanoke
High School.

THE SENIOR CLUB.

t/

o the junior class is due the credit of founding the first undergraduate club
ever instituted at the Johns Hopkins For several weeks past the ten
men who conceived the plan have been quietly engaged in making the
necessary arrangements. The name—The Senior Club—has been decided upon,
a constitution has been drawn up, and all that remains to make the the project
a reality is to select suitable quarters and begin the collection of dues. Every
1903 man has exhibited the usual class spirit by signing a slip stating that he
will contribute financially and otherwise to the success of the new organization,
and failure is out of the question. The club is to be strictly a senior institution
as the name signifies, and will be kept up each year by the graduating class at
the University. Those who take degrees will be numbered thereafter among
its honorary members.
It is not improbable that the idea was suggested by President Remsen's
short address at the annual athletic feed. In speaking of student organizations
for the promotion of social intercourse he referred in the highest terms to the
Houston Club of the University of Pennsylvania and expressed a wish that
Hopkins might, sometime, have a similar organization.
To those who have visited the magnificent quarters of the students at
Pennsylvania, our chances for such a club in the near future seem very slight.
Everything has a beginning, however, and some day may find the Senior Club
handsomely located among the many imposing buildings at Homewood.
In recognition of their work, the junior class elected the ten men, who have
crystallized the plans as members of the first board of governors. They will
assume active control next October, when the club will begin its existence.
They are: H. W Plaggemeyer, R. C. Hoffman, Jr., J. A. Addison, secretary;
H. K. Tootle, treasurer; R. C. Pagon, G. D. Strayer, J. T. Smith, C. M.
Riley, J. C. Hildt, and P. R. Straus.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

VERBICIDE!
Has the Thought Ever Struck You:
That a freshman can be told by his temperature, a junior by his humidity,
and a senior by his specific gravity;—
That science has invented no instrument delicate enough to fathom a post
graduate;—
That he is apt to be six feet tall, two feet wide, and one foot deep;—
That Carnegie Institute will be a valuable adjunct to the J. H. U.;—
That the two institutions may some day be connected by a boulevard;—
That it is to be hoped that there will be no mortgage on this end;—
That the magnificent property recently given our University is very hilly;—
That professors and students will have their ups and downs;—
That the people of Luzon and Samar are slow to love Uncle Sam;—
That someone must have told them we eat philopenas;—
That if American soldiers would give them a sample of our new college
yells, they would willingly surrender or die;—
That the world revolves on its axis;—
That for this reason everything is sure to come our way;—
That if we could travel eastward at the rate of about 1,000 miles an hour,
the sun would not go down;—
That the same day would continue so long as we traveled,—
That if we started on Sunday our rest day would last until we rested, and
no longer.
H. L. LLOYD, '04.
THE INTERCOLLEGIATE DEBATE.
FTER a year of hard work, the first intercollegiate debate in which Hopkins has ever participated takes place on Thursday of this week • The
two delegates from the University of North Carolina, Messrs. Williams,
'02, and Stearn, '02, are supposed to be from the best in the undergraduate
body, and our two men, Harry Plaggemeyer, '03, and H. B. Stone, '02, were
only chosen at the last moment. The trust question will be debated, North
Carolina defending the trust. The reception committee, which has succeeded
in making Baltimore comfortable for our guests, is composed of Ross M. Diggs,
chairman; Harvey B. Stone, John G. Campbell, Robinson C. Pagon, R. C.
Hoffman, Jr. Several of the Fraternities have kindly offered to quarter the
North Carolina speakers.

A MAGAZINE OF COLLEGE SPORTS.
ILLIAM B. DWIGHT (Yale '54) expects to fill a long felt want in the
college world by publishing a monthly magazine devoted exclusively
to college sports. The magazine will be known as the "Intercollegiate
News." Mr. Dwight, the editor, needs no introduction to those who are
interested in athletics, and his name at the head of the enterprise forecasts the
success that justly awaits such a publication.
Associate-editors are being secured in all the colleges so that the editor
will be in touch with collegiate conditions and be able to furnish up to date
news. Mr. W. B. Hill, manager of last season's foot ball team, will have
charge of the Hopkins correspondence.
The magazine will contain timely articles on all important questions of
athletics, and will prove of great value in making every one acquainted with
the conditions existing at the different colleges. This will be particularly valuable to Hopkins, since it furnishes an organ wherein we can explain the peculiar situation in which we are placed athletically.
